segment.source: Compare EGL code to DXGI and Direct3D
segment.target: Compare EGL code to DXGI and Direct3D

segment.source: The DirectX Graphics Interface (DXGI) and several Direct3D APIs serve the same role as EGL.
segment.target: The DirectX Graphics Interface (DXGI) and several Direct3D APIs serve the same role as EGL.

segment.source: This topic helps you understand DXGI and Direct3D 11 from the perspective of EGL.
segment.target: This topic helps you understand DXGI and Direct3D 11 from the perspective of EGL.

segment.source: Compare EGL code to DXGI and Direct3D
segment.target: Compare EGL code to DXGI and Direct3D

segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: ID3D11Device1
segment.target: ID3D11Device1

segment.source: ID3D11DeviceContext1
segment.target: ID3D11DeviceContext1

segment.source: CoreWindow
segment.target: CoreWindow

segment.source: The DirectX Graphics Interface (DXGI) and several Direct3D APIs serve the same role as EGL.
segment.target: The DirectX Graphics Interface (DXGI) and several Direct3D APIs serve the same role as EGL.

segment.source: This topic helps you understand DXGI and Direct3D 11 from the perspective of EGL.
segment.target: This topic helps you understand DXGI and Direct3D 11 from the perspective of EGL.

segment.source: DXGI and Direct3D, like EGL, provide methods to configure graphics resources, obtain a rendering context for your shaders to draw into, and to display the results in a window.
segment.target: DXGI and Direct3D, like EGL, provide methods to configure graphics resources, obtain a rendering context for your shaders to draw into, and to display the results in a window.

segment.source: However, DXGI and Direct3D have quite a few more options, and require more effort to set up correctly when porting from EGL.
segment.target: However, DXGI and Direct3D have quite a few more options, and require more effort to set up correctly when porting from EGL.

segment.source: Note This guidance is based off the Khronos Group's open specification for EGL 1.4, found here: Khronos Native Platform Graphics Interface (EGL Version 1.4 - April 6, 2011) \[PDF\].
segment.target: Note This guidance is based off the Khronos Group's open specification for EGL 1.4, found here: Khronos Native Platform Graphics Interface (EGL Version 1.4 - April 6, 2011) \[PDF\].

segment.source: Differences in syntax specific to other platforms and development languages are not covered in this guidance.
segment.target: Differences in syntax specific to other platforms and development languages are not covered in this guidance.

segment.source: How does DXGI and Direct3D compare?
segment.target: How does DXGI and Direct3D compare?

segment.source: The big advantage of EGL over DXGI and Direct3D is that it is relatively simple to start drawing to a window surface.
segment.target: The big advantage of EGL over DXGI and Direct3D is that it is relatively simple to start drawing to a window surface.

segment.source: This is because OpenGL ES 2.0—and therefore EGL—is a specification implemented by multiple platform providers, whereas DXGI and Direct3D are a single reference that hardware vendor drivers must conform to.
segment.target: This is because OpenGL ES 2.0—and therefore EGL—is a specification implemented by multiple platform providers, whereas DXGI and Direct3D are a single reference that hardware vendor drivers must conform to.

segment.source: This means that Microsoft must implement a set of APIs that enable the broadest possible set of vendor features, rather than focusing on a functional subset offered by a specific vendor, or by combining vendor-specific setup commands into simpler APIs.
segment.target: This means that Microsoft must implement a set of APIs that enable the broadest possible set of vendor features, rather than focusing on a functional subset offered by a specific vendor, or by combining vendor-specific setup commands into simpler APIs.

segment.source: On the other hand, Direct3D provides a single set of APIs that cover a very broad range of graphics hardware platforms and feature levels, and offer more flexibility for developers experienced with the platform.
segment.target: On the other hand, Direct3D provides a single set of APIs that cover a very broad range of graphics hardware platforms and feature levels, and offer more flexibility for developers experienced with the platform.

segment.source: Like EGL, DXGI and Direct3D provide APIs for the following behaviors:
segment.target: Like EGL, DXGI and Direct3D provide APIs for the following behaviors:

segment.source: Obtaining, and reading and writing to a frame buffer (called a "swap chain" in DXGI).
segment.target: Obtaining, and reading and writing to a frame buffer (called a "swap chain" in DXGI).

segment.source: Associating the frame buffer with a UI window.
segment.target: Associating the frame buffer with a UI window.

segment.source: Obtaining and configuring rendering contexts in which to draw.
segment.target: Obtaining and configuring rendering contexts in which to draw.

segment.source: Issuing commands to the graphics pipeline for a specific rendering context.
segment.target: Issuing commands to the graphics pipeline for a specific rendering context.

segment.source: Creating and managing shader resources, and associating them with a rendering content.
segment.target: Creating and managing shader resources, and associating them with a rendering content.

segment.source: Rendering to specific render targets (such as textures).
segment.target: Rendering to specific render targets (such as textures).

segment.source: Updating the window's display surface with the results of rendering with the graphics resources.
segment.target: Updating the window's display surface with the results of rendering with the graphics resources.

segment.source: To see the basic Direct3D process for configuring the graphics pipeline, check out the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template in Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: To see the basic Direct3D process for configuring the graphics pipeline, check out the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template in Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: The base rendering class in it provides a good baseline for setting up the Direct3D 11 graphics infrastructure and configuring basic resources on it, as well as supporting Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app features such as screen rotation.
segment.target: The base rendering class in it provides a good baseline for setting up the Direct3D 11 graphics infrastructure and configuring basic resources on it, as well as supporting Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app features such as screen rotation.

segment.source: EGL has very few APIs relative to Direct3D 11, and navigating the latter can be a challenge if you aren't familiar with the naming and jargon particular to the platform.
segment.target: EGL has very few APIs relative to Direct3D 11, and navigating the latter can be a challenge if you aren't familiar with the naming and jargon particular to the platform.

segment.source: Here's a simple overview to help you get oriented.
segment.target: Here's a simple overview to help you get oriented.

segment.source: First, review the basic EGL object to Direct3D interface mapping:
segment.target: First, review the basic EGL object to Direct3D interface mapping:

segment.source: EGL abstraction
segment.target: EGL abstraction

segment.source: Similar Direct3D representation
segment.target: Similar Direct3D representation

segment.source: EGLDisplay
segment.target: EGLDisplay

segment.source: In Direct3D (for UWP apps), the display handle is obtained through the Windows::UI::CoreWindow API (or the ICoreWindowInterop interface that exposes the HWND).
segment.target: In Direct3D (for UWP apps), the display handle is obtained through the Windows::UI::CoreWindow API (or the ICoreWindowInterop interface that exposes the HWND).

segment.source: The adapter and hardware configuration are set with the IDXGIAdapter and IDXGIDevice1 COM interfaces, respectively.
segment.target: The adapter and hardware configuration are set with the IDXGIAdapter and IDXGIDevice1 COM interfaces, respectively.

segment.source: EGLSurface
segment.target: EGLSurface

segment.source: In Direct3D, the buffers and other window resources (visible or offscreen) are created and configured by specific DXGI interfaces, including IDXGIFactory2 (a factory pattern implementation used to acquire DXGI resources such as theIDXGISwapChain1 (display buffers).
segment.target: In Direct3D, the buffers and other window resources (visible or offscreen) are created and configured by specific DXGI interfaces, including IDXGIFactory2 (a factory pattern implementation used to acquire DXGI resources such as theIDXGISwapChain1 (display buffers).

segment.source: The ID3D11Device1 that represents the graphics device and its resources, is acquired with D3D11Device::CreateDevice.
segment.target: The ID3D11Device1 that represents the graphics device and its resources, is acquired with D3D11Device::CreateDevice.

segment.source: For render targets, use the ID3D11RenderTargetView interface.
segment.target: For render targets, use the ID3D11RenderTargetView interface.

segment.source: EGLContext
segment.target: EGLContext

segment.source: In Direct3D, you configure and issue commands to the graphics pipeline with the ID3D11DeviceContext1 interface.
segment.target: In Direct3D, you configure and issue commands to the graphics pipeline with the ID3D11DeviceContext1 interface.

segment.source: EGLConfig
segment.target: EGLConfig

segment.source: In Direct3D 11, you create and configure graphics resources such as a buffers, textures, stencils and shaders with methods on the ID3D11Device1 interface.
segment.target: In Direct3D 11, you create and configure graphics resources such as a buffers, textures, stencils and shaders with methods on the ID3D11Device1 interface.

segment.source: Now, here's the most basic process for setting up a simple graphics display, resources and context in DXGI and Direct3D for a UWP app.
segment.target: Now, here's the most basic process for setting up a simple graphics display, resources and context in DXGI and Direct3D for a UWP app.

segment.source: Obtain a handle to the CoreWindow object for the app's core UI thread by calling CoreWindow::GetForCurrentThread.
segment.target: Obtain a handle to the CoreWindow object for the app's core UI thread by calling CoreWindow::GetForCurrentThread.

segment.source: For UWP apps, acquire a swap chain from the IDXGIAdapter2 with IDXGIFactory2::CreateSwapChainForCoreWindow, and pass it the CoreWindow reference you obtained in step 1.
segment.target: For UWP apps, acquire a swap chain from the IDXGIAdapter2 with IDXGIFactory2::CreateSwapChainForCoreWindow, and pass it the CoreWindow reference you obtained in step 1.

segment.source: You will get an IDXGISwapChain1 instance in return.
segment.target: You will get an IDXGISwapChain1 instance in return.

segment.source: Scope it to your renderer object and its rendering thread.
segment.target: Scope it to your renderer object and its rendering thread.

segment.source: Obtain ID3D11Device1 and ID3D11DeviceContext1 instances by calling the D3D11Device::CreateDevice method.
segment.target: Obtain ID3D11Device1 and ID3D11DeviceContext1 instances by calling the D3D11Device::CreateDevice method.

segment.source: Scope them to your renderer object as well.
segment.target: Scope them to your renderer object as well.

segment.source: Create shaders, textures, and other resources using methods on your renderer's ID3D11Device1 object.
segment.target: Create shaders, textures, and other resources using methods on your renderer's ID3D11Device1 object.

segment.source: Define buffers, run shaders and manage the pipeline stages using methods on your renderer's ID3D11DeviceContext1 object.
segment.target: Define buffers, run shaders and manage the pipeline stages using methods on your renderer's ID3D11DeviceContext1 object.

segment.source: When the pipeline has executed and a frame is drawn to the back buffer, present it to the screen with IDXGISwapChain1::Present1.
segment.target: When the pipeline has executed and a frame is drawn to the back buffer, present it to the screen with IDXGISwapChain1::Present1.

segment.source: To examine this process in more detail, review Getting started with DirectX graphics.
segment.target: To examine this process in more detail, review Getting started with DirectX graphics.

segment.source: The rest of this article covers many of the common steps for basic graphics pipeline setup and management.
segment.target: The rest of this article covers many of the common steps for basic graphics pipeline setup and management.

segment.source: Note Windows Desktop apps have different APIs for obtaining a Direct3D swap chain, such as D3D11Device::CreateDeviceAndSwapChain, and do not use a CoreWindow object.
segment.target: Note Windows Desktop apps have different APIs for obtaining a Direct3D swap chain, such as D3D11Device::CreateDeviceAndSwapChain, and do not use a CoreWindow object.

segment.source: Obtaining a window for display
segment.target: Obtaining a window for display

segment.source: In this example, eglGetDisplay is passed an HWND for a window resource specific to the Microsoft Windows platform.
segment.target: In this example, eglGetDisplay is passed an HWND for a window resource specific to the Microsoft Windows platform.

segment.source: Other platforms, such as Apple's iOS (Cocoa) and Google's Android, have different handles or references to window resources, and may have different calling syntax altogether.
segment.target: Other platforms, such as Apple's iOS (Cocoa) and Google's Android, have different handles or references to window resources, and may have different calling syntax altogether.

segment.source: After obtaining a display, you initialize it, set the preferred configuration, and create a surface with a back buffer you can draw into.
segment.target: After obtaining a display, you initialize it, set the preferred configuration, and create a surface with a back buffer you can draw into.

segment.source: Obtaining a display and configuring it with EGL..
segment.target: Obtaining a display and configuring it with EGL..

segment.source: In Direct3D, a UWP app's main window is represented by the CoreWindow object, which can be obtained from the app object by calling CoreWindow::GetForCurrentThread as part of the initialization process of the "view provider" you construct for Direct3D.
segment.target: In Direct3D, a UWP app's main window is represented by the CoreWindow object, which can be obtained from the app object by calling CoreWindow::GetForCurrentThread as part of the initialization process of the "view provider" you construct for Direct3D.

segment.source: (If you are using Direct3D-XAML interop, you use the XAML framework's view provider.) The process for creating a Direct3D view provider is covered in How to set up your app to display a view.
segment.target: (If you are using Direct3D-XAML interop, you use the XAML framework's view provider.) The process for creating a Direct3D view provider is covered in How to set up your app to display a view.

segment.source: Obtaining a CoreWindow for Direct3D.
segment.target: Obtaining a CoreWindow for Direct3D.

segment.source: Once the CoreWindow reference is obtained, the window must be activated, which executes the Run method of your main object and begins window event processing.
segment.target: Once the CoreWindow reference is obtained, the window must be activated, which executes the Run method of your main object and begins window event processing.

segment.source: After that, create an ID3D11Device1 and an ID3D11DeviceContext1, and use them to get the underlying IDXGIDevice1 and IDXGIAdapter so you can obtain an IDXGIFactory2 object to create a swap chain resource based on your DXGI\_SWAP\_CHAIN\_DESC1 configuration.
segment.target: After that, create an ID3D11Device1 and an ID3D11DeviceContext1, and use them to get the underlying IDXGIDevice1 and IDXGIAdapter so you can obtain an IDXGIFactory2 object to create a swap chain resource based on your DXGI\_SWAP\_CHAIN\_DESC1 configuration.

segment.source: Configuring and setting the DXGI swap chain on the CoreWindow for Direct3D.
segment.target: Configuring and setting the DXGI swap chain on the CoreWindow for Direct3D.

segment.source: Call the IDXGISwapChain1::Present1 method after you prepare a frame in order to display it.
segment.target: Call the IDXGISwapChain1::Present1 method after you prepare a frame in order to display it.

segment.source: Note that in Direct3D 11, there isn't an abstraction identical to EGLSurface.
segment.target: Note that in Direct3D 11, there isn't an abstraction identical to EGLSurface.

segment.source: (There is IDXGISurface1, but it is used differently.) The closest conceptual approximation is the ID3D11RenderTargetView object that we use to assign a texture (ID3D11Texture2D) as the back buffer that our shader pipeline will draw into.
segment.target: (There is IDXGISurface1, but it is used differently.) The closest conceptual approximation is the ID3D11RenderTargetView object that we use to assign a texture (ID3D11Texture2D) as the back buffer that our shader pipeline will draw into.

segment.source: Setting up the back buffer for the swap chain in Direct3D 11
segment.target: Setting up the back buffer for the swap chain in Direct3D 11

segment.source: A good practice is to call this code whenever the window is created or changes size.
segment.target: A good practice is to call this code whenever the window is created or changes size.

segment.source: During rendering, set the render target view with ID3D11DeviceContext1::OMSetRenderTargets before setting up any other subresources like vertex buffers or shaders.
segment.target: During rendering, set the render target view with ID3D11DeviceContext1::OMSetRenderTargets before setting up any other subresources like vertex buffers or shaders.

segment.source: Creating a rendering context
segment.target: Creating a rendering context

segment.source: In EGL 1.4, a "display" represents a set of window resources.
segment.target: In EGL 1.4, a "display" represents a set of window resources.

segment.source: Typically, you configure a "surface" for the display by supplying a set of attributes to the display object and getting a surface in return.
segment.target: Typically, you configure a "surface" for the display by supplying a set of attributes to the display object and getting a surface in return.

segment.source: You create a context for displaying the contents of the surface by creating that context and binding it to the surface and the display.
segment.target: You create a context for displaying the contents of the surface by creating that context and binding it to the surface and the display.

segment.source: The call flow usually looks similar to this:
segment.target: The call flow usually looks similar to this:

segment.source: Call eglGetDisplay with the handle to a display or window resource and obtain a display object.
segment.target: Call eglGetDisplay with the handle to a display or window resource and obtain a display object.

segment.source: Initialize the display with eglInitialize.
segment.target: Initialize the display with eglInitialize.

segment.source: Obtain the available display configuration and select one with eglGetConfigs and eglChooseConfig.
segment.target: Obtain the available display configuration and select one with eglGetConfigs and eglChooseConfig.

segment.source: Create a window surface with eglCreateWindowSurface.
segment.target: Create a window surface with eglCreateWindowSurface.

segment.source: Create a display context for drawing with eglCreateContext.
segment.target: Create a display context for drawing with eglCreateContext.

segment.source: Bind the display context to the display and the surface with eglMakeCurrent.
segment.target: Bind the display context to the display and the surface with eglMakeCurrent.

segment.source: n the previous section, we created the EGLDisplay and the EGLSurface, and now we use the EGLDisplay to create a context and associate that context with the display, using the configured EGLSurface to parameterize the output.
segment.target: n the previous section, we created the EGLDisplay and the EGLSurface, and now we use the EGLDisplay to create a context and associate that context with the display, using the configured EGLSurface to parameterize the output.

segment.source: Obtaining a rendering context with EGL 1.4
segment.target: Obtaining a rendering context with EGL 1.4

segment.source: A rendering context in Direct3D 11 is represented by an ID3D11Device1 object, which represents the adapter and allows you to create Direct3D resources such as buffers and shaders; and by the ID3D11DeviceContext1 object, which allows you to manage the graphics pipeline and execute the shaders.
segment.target: A rendering context in Direct3D 11 is represented by an ID3D11Device1 object, which represents the adapter and allows you to create Direct3D resources such as buffers and shaders; and by the ID3D11DeviceContext1 object, which allows you to manage the graphics pipeline and execute the shaders.

segment.source: Be aware of Direct3D feature levels!
segment.target: Be aware of Direct3D feature levels!

segment.source: These are used to support older Direct3D hardware platforms, from DirectX 9.1 to DirectX 11.
segment.target: These are used to support older Direct3D hardware platforms, from DirectX 9.1 to DirectX 11.

segment.source: Many platforms that use low power graphics hardware, such as tablets, only have access to DirectX 9.1 features, and older supported graphics hardware could be from 9.1 through 11.
segment.target: Many platforms that use low power graphics hardware, such as tablets, only have access to DirectX 9.1 features, and older supported graphics hardware could be from 9.1 through 11.

segment.source: Creating a rendering context with DXGI and Direct3D
segment.target: Creating a rendering context with DXGI and Direct3D

segment.source: Drawing into a texture or pixmap resource
segment.target: Drawing into a texture or pixmap resource

segment.source: To draw into a texture with OpenGL ES 2.0, configure a pixel buffer, or PBuffer.
segment.target: To draw into a texture with OpenGL ES 2.0, configure a pixel buffer, or PBuffer.

segment.source: After you successfully a configure and create an EGLSurface for it you can supply it with a rendering context and execute the shader pipeline to draw into the texture.
segment.target: After you successfully a configure and create an EGLSurface for it you can supply it with a rendering context and execute the shader pipeline to draw into the texture.

segment.source: Draw into a pixel buffer with OpenGL ES 2.0
segment.target: Draw into a pixel buffer with OpenGL ES 2.0

segment.source: In Direct3D 11, you create an ID3D11Texture2D resource and makei it a render target.
segment.target: In Direct3D 11, you create an ID3D11Texture2D resource and makei it a render target.

segment.source: Configure the render target using D3D11\_RENDER\_TARGET\_VIEW\_DESC.
segment.target: Configure the render target using D3D11\_RENDER\_TARGET\_VIEW\_DESC.

segment.source: When you call the ID3D11DeviceContext::Draw method(or a similar Draw\* operation on the device context) using this render target, the results are drawn into a texture.
segment.target: When you call the ID3D11DeviceContext::Draw method(or a similar Draw\* operation on the device context) using this render target, the results are drawn into a texture.

segment.source: Draw into a texture with Direct3D 11
segment.target: Draw into a texture with Direct3D 11

segment.source: This texture can be passed to a shader if it is associated with an ID3D11ShaderResourceView.
segment.target: This texture can be passed to a shader if it is associated with an ID3D11ShaderResourceView.

segment.source: Drawing to the screen
segment.target: Drawing to the screen

segment.source: Once you have used your EGLContext to configure your buffers and update your data, you run the shaders bound to it and draw the results to the back buffer with glDrawElements.
segment.target: Once you have used your EGLContext to configure your buffers and update your data, you run the shaders bound to it and draw the results to the back buffer with glDrawElements.

segment.source: You display the back buffer by calling eglSwapBuffers.
segment.target: You display the back buffer by calling eglSwapBuffers.

segment.source: Open GL ES 2.0: Drawing to the screen.
segment.target: Open GL ES 2.0: Drawing to the screen.

segment.source: In Direct3D 11, you configure your buffers and bind shaders with your IDXGISwapChain::Present1.
segment.target: In Direct3D 11, you configure your buffers and bind shaders with your IDXGISwapChain::Present1.

segment.source: Then you call one of the ID3D11DeviceContext1::Draw\* methods to run the shaders and draw the results to a render target configured as the back buffer for the swap chain.
segment.target: Then you call one of the ID3D11DeviceContext1::Draw\* methods to run the shaders and draw the results to a render target configured as the back buffer for the swap chain.

segment.source: After that, you simply present the back buffer to the display by calling IDXGISwapChain::Present1.
segment.target: After that, you simply present the back buffer to the display by calling IDXGISwapChain::Present1.

segment.source: Direct3D 11: Drawing to the screen.
segment.target: Direct3D 11: Drawing to the screen.

segment.source: Releasing graphics resources
segment.target: Releasing graphics resources

segment.source: In EGL, you release the window resources by passing the EGLDisplay to eglTerminate.
segment.target: In EGL, you release the window resources by passing the EGLDisplay to eglTerminate.

segment.source: Terminating a display with EGL 1.4
segment.target: Terminating a display with EGL 1.4

segment.source: In a UWP app, you can close the CoreWindow with CoreWindow::Close, although this can only be used for secondary UI windows.
segment.target: In a UWP app, you can close the CoreWindow with CoreWindow::Close, although this can only be used for secondary UI windows.

segment.source: The primary UI thread and its associated CoreWindow cannot be closed; rather, they are expired by the operating system.
segment.target: The primary UI thread and its associated CoreWindow cannot be closed; rather, they are expired by the operating system.

segment.source: However, when a secondary CoreWindow is closed, the CoreWindow::Closed event is raised.
segment.target: However, when a secondary CoreWindow is closed, the CoreWindow::Closed event is raised.

segment.source: API Reference mapping for EGL to Direct3D 11
segment.target: API Reference mapping for EGL to Direct3D 11

segment.source: EGL API
segment.target: EGL API

segment.source: Similar Direct3D 11 API or behavior
segment.target: Similar Direct3D 11 API or behavior

segment.source: eglBindAPI
segment.target: eglBindAPI

segment.source: N/A.
segment.target: N/A.

segment.source: eglBindTexImage
segment.target: eglBindTexImage

segment.source: Call ID3D11Device::CreateTexture2D to set a 2D texture.
segment.target: Call ID3D11Device::CreateTexture2D to set a 2D texture.

segment.source: eglChooseConfig
segment.target: eglChooseConfig

segment.source: Direct3D does not supply a set of default frame buffer configurations.
segment.target: Direct3D does not supply a set of default frame buffer configurations.

segment.source: The swap chain's configuration
segment.target: The swap chain's configuration

segment.source: eglCopyBuffers
segment.target: eglCopyBuffers

segment.source: To copy a buffer data, call ID3D11DeviceContext::CopyStructureCount.
segment.target: To copy a buffer data, call ID3D11DeviceContext::CopyStructureCount.

segment.source: To copy a resource, call ID3DDeviceCOntext::CopyResource.
segment.target: To copy a resource, call ID3DDeviceCOntext::CopyResource.

segment.source: eglCreateContext
segment.target: eglCreateContext

segment.source: Create a Direct3D device context by calling D3D11CreateDevice, which returns both a handle to a Direct3D device and a default Direct3D immediate context (ID3D11DeviceContext1 object).
segment.target: Create a Direct3D device context by calling D3D11CreateDevice, which returns both a handle to a Direct3D device and a default Direct3D immediate context (ID3D11DeviceContext1 object).

segment.source: You can also create a Direct3D deferred context by calling ID3D11Device2::CreateDeferredContext on the returned ID3D11Device1 object.
segment.target: You can also create a Direct3D deferred context by calling ID3D11Device2::CreateDeferredContext on the returned ID3D11Device1 object.

segment.source: eglCreatePbufferFromClientBuffer
segment.target: eglCreatePbufferFromClientBuffer

segment.source: All buffers are read and written as a Direct3D subresource, such as an ID3D11Texture2D.
segment.target: All buffers are read and written as a Direct3D subresource, such as an ID3D11Texture2D.

segment.source: Copy from one to another compatible subresource type with a methods such as ID3D11DeviceContext1:CopyResource.
segment.target: Copy from one to another compatible subresource type with a methods such as ID3D11DeviceContext1:CopyResource.

segment.source: eglCreatePbufferSurface
segment.target: eglCreatePbufferSurface

segment.source: To create a Direct3D device with no swap chain, call the static D3D11CreateDevice method.
segment.target: To create a Direct3D device with no swap chain, call the static D3D11CreateDevice method.

segment.source: For a Direct3D render target view, call ID3D11Device::CreateRenderTargetView.
segment.target: For a Direct3D render target view, call ID3D11Device::CreateRenderTargetView.

segment.source: eglCreatePixmapSurface
segment.target: eglCreatePixmapSurface

segment.source: To create a Direct3D device with no swap chain, call the static D3D11CreateDevice method.
segment.target: To create a Direct3D device with no swap chain, call the static D3D11CreateDevice method.

segment.source: For a Direct3D render target view, call ID3D11Device::CreateRenderTargetView.
segment.target: For a Direct3D render target view, call ID3D11Device::CreateRenderTargetView.

segment.source: eglCreateWindowSurface
segment.target: eglCreateWindowSurface

segment.source: Ontain an IDXGISwapChain1 (for the display buffers) and an ID3D11Device1 (a virtual interface for the graphics device and its resources).
segment.target: Ontain an IDXGISwapChain1 (for the display buffers) and an ID3D11Device1 (a virtual interface for the graphics device and its resources).

segment.source: Use the ID3D11Device1 to define an ID3D11RenderTargetView that you can use to create the frame buffer you supply to the IDXGISwapChain1.
segment.target: Use the ID3D11Device1 to define an ID3D11RenderTargetView that you can use to create the frame buffer you supply to the IDXGISwapChain1.

segment.source: eglDestroyContext
segment.target: eglDestroyContext

segment.source: N/A.
segment.target: N/A.

segment.source: Use ID3D11DeviceContext::DiscardView1 to get rid of a render target view.
segment.target: Use ID3D11DeviceContext::DiscardView1 to get rid of a render target view.

segment.source: To close the parent ID3D11DeviceContext1, set the instance to null and wait for the platform to reclaim its resources.
segment.target: To close the parent ID3D11DeviceContext1, set the instance to null and wait for the platform to reclaim its resources.

segment.source: You cannot destroy the device context directly.
segment.target: You cannot destroy the device context directly.

segment.source: eglDestroySurface
segment.target: eglDestroySurface

segment.source: N/A.
segment.target: N/A.

segment.source: Graphics resources are cleaned up when the UWP app's CoreWindow is closed by the platform.
segment.target: Graphics resources are cleaned up when the UWP app's CoreWindow is closed by the platform.

segment.source: Call CoreWindow::GetForCurrentThread to get a reference to the current main app window.
segment.target: Call CoreWindow::GetForCurrentThread to get a reference to the current main app window.

segment.source: This is the current ID3D11RenderTargetView.
segment.target: This is the current ID3D11RenderTargetView.

segment.source: Typically, this is scoped to your renderer object.
segment.target: Typically, this is scoped to your renderer object.

segment.source: eglGetError
segment.target: eglGetError

segment.source: Errors are obtained as HRESULTs returned by most methods on DirectX interfaces.
segment.target: Errors are obtained as HRESULTs returned by most methods on DirectX interfaces.

segment.source: If the method does not return an HRESULT, call GetLastError.
segment.target: If the method does not return an HRESULT, call GetLastError.

segment.source: To convert a system error into an HRESULT value, use the HRESULT\_FROM\_WIN32 macro.
segment.target: To convert a system error into an HRESULT value, use the HRESULT\_FROM\_WIN32 macro.
